feed.title: Current Watches, Warnings and Advisories for the United States Issued by the National Weather Service

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued June 22 at 2:17PM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...POTENTIAL MARINE LAYER FOLLOWED BY WARMER THAN NORMAL TEMPERATURES HEADING INTO NEXT WEEK... Warmer than normal temperatures are expected by late this weekend as temperatures rise by a couple degrees each day. The warmest days are expected to be early next week with highs in the mid 70s and continued dry conditions.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Cape Decision to Salisbury Sound Coastal Area; Cape Fairweather to Cape Suckling Coastal Area; Dixon Entrance to Cape Decision Coastal Area; Salisbury Sound to Cape Fairweather Coastal Area

entry.summary: ...SIGNIFICANTLY WARMER THAN NORMAL TEMPERATURES HEADING INTO NEXT WEEK... The warmest days are expected to be early next week with highs in the upper 80s and continued dry conditions.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued June 22 at 8:24PM PDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...A strong thunderstorm will impact portions of north central San Benito County through 915 PM PDT... entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued June 22 at 8:18PM PDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...Strong outflow winds from a strong thunderstorm will impact portions of west central Fresno County through 900 PM PDT... At 815 PM PDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm 19 miles west of Cantua Creek, or 44 miles east of Arroyo Seco, moving north at 10 mph. Although no rain may fall, strong wind gusts may still occur.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued June 22 at 6:52AM PDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...FIRST HEAT WAVE OF 2022 EXPECTED SATURDAY THROUGH MONDAY... After an unusually cool and wet spring, a rapid warm-up is expected late this week, with temperatures peaking Saturday through Monday across western Washington. Most lowland and mountain valley locations will see temperatures peaking in the 80s to around 90 degrees by Sunday.
